author: Trudie Barreras
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: Having previously reviewed a YA novel by author Luanne Rice (“The Beautiful Lost” reviewed for Vine in June of 2017), I was delighted to be offered her suspense novel “Last Day” as one of my Amazon Prime “first reads” for January 2020. As I said in my earlier review, Rice delves potently into serious relationship issues, and her understanding of them, and development of plot lines based on early trauma, are unparalleled.The narrative begins with the brutal murder of Beth, one of two sisters who, as teens, spent 22 hours tied up in the basement of the family gallery with their mother. All three were gagged, and the mother suffocated as a result. The girls survived, but were, in very different ways, PTSD sufferers. Kate, the elder sister (though they were only a year apart) walled herself off and became a pilot, highly competent but very asocial, while Beth, who married, continued to run the gallery. At the time she was killed, Beth was the mother of a 16-year-old daughter Sam, was also pregnant with a boy baby (who died with her) and was experiencing marital difficulties. Kate, who had been flying a cross-country charter flight, arrived home frantic because Beth had returned none of her phone calls, and having the police break into the house, found her sister’s body.The story is gripping and nuanced, and the characters are meticulously developed. The cast includes not only the sisters, but their two best friends, Lulu and Scottie; Sam; the husbands of Beth and Scottie; and the various detectives on the case; as well as Scottie’s daughters Isabel and Julie. In addition there are peripheral characters who turn out to have important roles in the story. Although this book was not one which I am obligated to review as part of my Vine commitment, I found it thoroughly enjoyable and deeply engaging, and I recommend it highly.
title: Thoroughly enjoyable and deeply engaging

author: Deborah  W. Lesley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2020
review_content: I truly am not sure how I feel after completing this book. I guess it shows that the way in which you are perceived is very important. Often that becomes more important than the real you. I would think most of us know someone well who is seen by the outside world in a specific way yet as a person who knows him/ her better, we know another side.This book opens with a murder...the murder of a woman ( Beth) whose mother had also been murdered. The same police officer assigned to the mother’s murder is assigned to the daughter’s murder.Central to the story is the closeness of four friends, best friends since childhood. One of the friends, Kate, is our victim’s sister.  Kate and Beth, always close, were not as close as she thought, which upsets Kate. She doesn’t understand and her confusion is compounded by the secrets that come out in the months following the murder.Perceptions, the way we are seen by others, plays a vital role. What is it like to have become involved in some way with the victim? What is it like to have a record plus a connection to the murder? What is it like to be a cheating spouse? And so much more.... secrets from the past can be important yet today’s secrets can be deadly.Missing some character development, the reader can figure out these people from surrounding conversations. And at the end, you are left wondering, what will happen to those who loved or were loved by Beth, our victim.
title: History Repeating Itself?

author: KReader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
review_content: This book was a huge disappointment for me and I'm giving it three stars to be nice.  Based on all the glowing reviews, I was expecting something different, something more. What I got was a convoluted family drama and story about friendships that often bordered on feeling like a Harlequin romance. The writing style was all tell, no show,  the dialogue wooden, and there were so many unbelievable things from the way the daughter and sister grieved at the beginning to the seasoned detective forgetting to do an autopsy on the unborn child. I also found it unbelievable that the sister didn't recognize the detective from the get go and found the murderer's motive ridiculous. I almost gave up reading this torturous book, but managed to skim it to the end. The only character I liked and rooted for was Clementine the rabbit. At least, she got a HFN ending. If you like gripping, twisty domestic, fast paced thrillers, this book ISN'T for you. Sadly, I will not be reading one of Luanne Rice's books again.
title: Not For Me

author: Greta Gustafsson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2020
review_content: I'm not going who into too much detail with this as the basic plot is known. The characters were interesting as well as her writing style. I was invested in it until the very end. I didn't buy  the ending however, it made no sense to me whatsoever. It wrapped up way too quickly with barely an explanation. I found it incredulous and ultimately extremely frustrating.
title: She had me until the end

author: Mac's Books
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2020
review_content: Luanne Rice is a master storyteller and that truly shines in her latest novel, Last Day, the story of four friends, two deaths and the secrets kept hidden to the end.Sisters Kate and Beth had survived a tragic ordeal in their teen years but, like so many, that tragedy pushed them apart rather than pulling them together. Kate is closed off from all emotion and Beth has infused her life with love, giving to the community, loving her daughter and caring for her friends. When Beth is murdered, Kate digs in to find the answers to her sister's murder. What she finds instead are layers of secrets.While I was a bit disappointed in the ending, the overall story is brilliantly told.
title: A Masterful, Well Told Story

author: Florida Twins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: I found the overall premise of the book promising. A traumatic history, lifelong friends, secrets and lies. Sadly, the characters were undeveloped and disjointed. I can't picture a single one of them. When the dead sister joined the narrative, I could not have rolled my eyes more. I wish the grandmother had still been alive. She seemed the most interesting of the lot. This book was a fail for me.
title: Not Impressed

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2020
review_content: I got offered this book free as part of Amazon Prime, so gave it a try. Had never read this author before and will not read her other works, now that I see how superficial her writing is. She throws in lots of pretty references to the Connecticut coast and some pretty turns of phrase, but all the characters seemed phoney to me. I grew up in a coastal town in Connecticut but in a different part of the state than where thus story is set, so I did enjoy some of the descriptions of nature in this novel, but I was annoyed by the actual story and characters.  The plot held my interest somewhat, as I wondered who committed the murder, however I found the main characters' friendships a bit fake. The author tried to conjure a sense of deep emotional bonds between a group of four women, but it just came off as contrived. I didn't feel or care much for any of the characters, and towards the end of the book the author threw in several last-minute red herrings, to suddenly make it seem that any of these pretentious women might have hidden motives to kill. And the mystery of the stolen painting turned out to be a very "meh" mystery. This is a lightweight beach-read pretending to be profound. Don't waste your money or time on it.
title: Superficial Fluff, pretending to be more

author: Big Mo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2020
review_content: What an absolute waste of time!  I am a very patient reader - and I hung in there on this one - ALL the way through - hoping it would get better.  Extremely poorly written, disjointed etc.  The plot was horrible and the ending was very disappointing.  The book was full of wasted, meaningless words  that simply took up space on the page.  This book was free (Amazon Reads) - I should have been paid to read this one.  Full of new age, reincarnation, lesbian relationships, broken marriages, affairs, kids cutting themselves, etc.  Avoid this one at all cost - don't waste your time.
title: One Of The Worst Books I Have Ever Read

author: John Sawyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: There is a murder. There are subtle clues hinting at who did it. There are some interesting red herrings. There are two strange chapters (52 & 60). I was somewhat disappointed with the motivation for the murder. Just my thought; you may like the motivation. I recall there were some time line anomalies. There were a couple of unexpected (to me anyway) mistakes made by some characters, necessary to support the narrative and keep the mystery going.  Character development was excellent, especially through the dialogues. The book focus was more on the interaction of two sisters and their relationships with friends and significant others; less on solving the murder. To me, It was definitely a book of relationships and love.  The murder provided the impetus and background for exploring those relationships. Overall an entertaining read.
title: Enjoyable Read

author: Annette G.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: Too many bad things happening to the same family over the course of two generations. A detective who is obsessed with the survivors. How old is he? I couldn't figure him out, even though I thought he could have been an interesting character.I couldn’t really picture any character well, they were all blurry and blah. And not one of them was likable.Kate and the girlfriends are whiny. Kate seems to love her Porsche more than anything.I wanted to give the book 3 stars because the writing style was good, but when I got to the part where we read chapters from the dead woman’s POV, the author lost me.There were too many unanswered questions left at the end, too. It feels as if this book needed some serious rewriting. Including working out the motive for the killer better. It wasn't a big surprise who it was, but the killer's reasons were lax.
title: too far-fetched storyline.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2020
review_content: I loved this book. I kept reading. I had a hard time putting it down to sleep. I just wanted to find out “who did it”. All the characters in the book had flaws. No one was perfect, they all had some likable traits as well as unlikable ones.It’s amazing how you can have friends from childhood and think you really know them. It’s the same for the sisters in this novel.I didn’t like the ending however I didn’t write the book. I wanted more answers. Life doesn’t always tie everything up into a neat bow and this boom didn’t either.
title: A good book, hard to put down, worth the hours to read it.

author: Chris Prehn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
review_content: I'd give this a solid 4 stars.What I liked:~ the relaxed writing style -- everything felt gentle and meandering, and it worked for me~ the multi-POV -- I almost always prefer books with this approach, so I definitely enjoyed it here (although it was a little jarring when Beth had a turn)~ the complexity of the characters -- no one was clear-cut here, and I appreciated the different layers to them allWhat wasn't quite as strong:~ I felt like we didn't really get close to any of the characters -- in short, I wanted to know more about them, especially to learn what happened to them say two or three years down the road. I don't always need an epilogue, but I felt like this story could have used one~ motives and character growth -- I felt like the motives given for the killer were on the weak side, and it seemed a little over-the-top; plus, the character growth was pretty minimal. To my understanding, most of the characters stayed relatively the same throughout the book, and although I enjoyed getting to know them, I wanted to see something change in their livesAll in all, I enjoyed reading it, but I doubt I'll re-read it. This was my first Luanne Rice book, and if I liked the flap copy, I'd probably pick up another one.
title: Pleasant Read

author: Bonnye Reed Fry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
review_content: I received a free electronic copy of this excellent novel from author Luanne Rice and Thomas & Mercer Publisher. Thank you all for sharing your hard work with me. I have read this novel of my own volition, and this review reflects my honest opinion of this work. I am pleased to recommend Luanne Rice to friends and family. She writes an excellent tale.Luanne Rice creates a tightly drawn tale about family relationships and what makes a friendship work. 'Last Day' is an excellent story wrapped around four besties, now pushing 40, but devoted friends from childhood on. We see the relationships they all have with their children, and what it takes to keep it all together when one of those stanchions of the neighborhood and a lifetime of sharing is taken before her time. Illness might be overcome, but this was obviously murder. Again. As was the murder of Helen Woodward. It brings back all the pain and angst of the murder of Beth and Kate's mother 23 years ago. Those relationships that look firm and tight from afar - really aren't. Where can you go for facts when everyone is remembering only how it used to be? Someone is lying. Who?1 like
title: A very interesting read!

author: SouthernGal820
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2020
review_content: This is a pretty gruesome book with a story that is just too weak.  Sadly there isn't a lot of to like about any of the characters, including the victim.  The redeeming characters for me was the detective, his brother and Jed. Overall the women characters were forgettable, not dimensional enough to really like them or feel attached to them.  The basement part of the story with Kate, Beth and their Mom was stupid and the ending felt rushed, no explanation for why the murderer killed Beth and honestly felt like the writer was just grasping at a straw to give a shocking ending.  Do not recommend this book unless you can read it for free and even then, a waste of time.
title: Horrible Ending

author: RRJCRVT2912
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
review_content: My opinion of this story is it is excellent. Luanne Rice wrote so beautifully of areas in Connecticut where the story takes place I find I want to visit. I really hope that wasn’t fiction. The story pulled me in quickly & kept my attention all the way through. The characters were interesting & I wished I couldknow most of them. The perp was a surprise because I wouldn’t have believed it without out reading it on the page. In hindsight there wereclues; sometimes I wondered if “this or that” was THE clue. I won’t say if I got it right or not. I do have one itty bitty complaint, the ending. I somehow felt a bit robbed but most likely either there will be more of this main character in a next installment (not really??) or Ms Rice wasn’t a paid Disney author. I recommend this novel because just a page or two could not spoil this beautifully written story.
title: 5 stars for characters, location descriptions, I was taken by surprise!

author: Jjspina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
review_content: Last Day is a chilling mystery that kept this reader glued until the shocking ending! This is a story about two sisters who suffer from a horrific experience when they are tied up along with their mother while a painting is stolen from their gallery. During this time their mother loses her life when she chokes on the bindings that secure her mouth.Beth and Kate, the two sisters, never get over their mother’s death and are scarred mentally and psychologically. They try to go on but Kate can’t open up with her feelings or feel love or any other kind of emotion. During this time Conor Reid, the detective who was on the case watches over the sisters for he feels their angst and wants to help in some way by solving the mystery of who took the painting and caused the death of their mother, Mathilde. In the mix are the sisters’ friends Lulu and Scotty who do their best to stay close to them.The author has created intriguing characters, twists and turns that keep the reader on edge guessing who and what happened and displays a shocking ending that will grip you. I highly recommend this chilling tale.
title: A Chilling Mystery!

author: Malew
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2020
review_content: I really enjoyed this book, although it could have  moved along considerably faster. It was a long  but worth it. The characters were interesting and you felt that you know the victim, through the observations of friends and relatives and her own voice at the end. Interesting. This is my first book by this author. Although I liked her writing, there was some repetition. The dog, for example, did an awful lot of bounding. There was a lot of outdated talk about hearts drawn in blood. And the idea that four friends could remain without secrets for life is charming, but a little disingenuous to this jaundiced soul. So it is  not one to go down in memory but definitely good entertainment.
title: A good suspenseful read

author: Darinda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2020
review_content: When Beth and Kate Lathrop were teenagers, they suffered a tragedy that left their mother dead and a valuable painting stolen. Now, Beth and Kate are grown, and it seems life is repeating itself when Beth is found murdered and the same painting is once again missing.A lot of characters and points of view, though the story is primarily from Kate's POV. Kate discovers her sister Beth has been murdered. Conor is the detective working the case, and he has a link to the sister's past. Pete is Beth's husband and a primary suspect in her death. Nicola is Pete's mistress. Sam is Beth and Pete's daughter. There are also a lot of friends mentioned throughout the book.This book hooked me at the start, but disappointed me in the end. It's a good mystery, and I imagine a lot of readers will enjoy it. For me, the number of characters and their various stories bogged down the novel. While some tangents were entertaining, the primary mystery was the only thing I was interested in. Disturbing and mysterious.
title: Disturbing and mysterious

author: Book Junkie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: No Spoilers in my reviews 🙂I was once again quite taken with Luanne Rice's excellent way with words and unique way of delving into the human soul. It is a very evocative tale, one that easily draws you in and keeps you guessing with a side story that doesn't excellent job of holding the beauty and horror of the main story aloft.The characters are written very realistically, I found myself becoming very familiar with each person that Ms Rice captured in her brilliant weaving of this tale. This is not a mere book, It's a haunting look at love, loss, what is truly important in life and the trespasses that can break us. It's a truly excellent novel, a credit to an already highly respected author.I feel completely comfortable with each of my five stars I award, as this was sheer excellence in contemporary literature and mystery.As always I wish happy reads to all, from The Unapologetic Book Junkie.
title: Soulful, Engaging, and Haunting Mystery

author: Bianca Bowers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: Reading this book was like eavesdropping on a  conversation full of name-dropping, and the overall pace, writing style and storyline reads more like a domestic drama than a thriller/suspense.Rice excels at anchoring the reader in time and place with dazzling, lush, and emotive descriptions:—“the painting cut from the frame; the pale-red heart drawn on the back; the canvas yellowed with age, its edges unraveling;”——“Migratory birds, resting on their journey south from the boreal forest, darted around the thicket. A yellow warbler, perched for ten seconds on the silver-tipped branch of a bayberry bush, looked like pure gold.”But the characters were one dimensional and lacked substance. There was a lot of unnecessary padding, which slowed the pace at times and had me skipping instead of turning pages.The backstory (of Kate, Beth and their mother in the basement) is repeated ad nauseum, and the author relies too much on that backstory to build what are essentially cookie-cutter, one dimensional characters that fall flat. For instance, Kate is a pilot, and that metaphor of restlessness and transience is heavily relied on to imbue Kate’s character and interior life. Beth, is nauseatingly kind and good, with many many mentions of her selfless work down at the soup kitchen—never mind the fact that she’s a privileged woman with nothing better to do. Detective Reid’s character also lacked dimension and depth, with Rice relying again on the sisters’ trauma and anchoring it as the only defining (and disturbing) moment in his life.If this was television, Last Day would be a network show—glossy, lacking substance, and written around commercial breaks.
title: Dazzling descriptions but lacked depth

author: Linda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2020
review_content: Although I do a lot of reading and enjoy books of many different categories, I don't usually write reviews.  For some reason I am compelled to "complain" about the ending of this one.  I like that the author gives little twists and turns throughout the book in order to lead the reader in different directions when guessing who the guilty party might be.  The characters are believable and the plot is not implausible.  The end however left me...."huh!"  The author tells us who did it but did not adequately flush out the "why".  The explanation by the perpetrator was extremely lacking and almost glossed over.  We know who did it and the why, but the big miss is that we don't know why it was done in that manner.  It is almost as if by the time the author got there, she was tired of the story and just wanted to end it.  I found that part unsatisfactory.
title: Ending could have been better

author: Lisa Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
review_content: This was a good story, and then the last few chapters got weird. First, we get metaphysical, hearing from the dead for the first time. Then, when the final twist is revealed, there is so little understanding of what happened that it removes much of the power of the twist. I was left feeling cheated. I’d give the first 80% 5 stars, and the last 20% 2stars.
title: The last part a disappointment

author: cosmikat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020
review_content: Asking if the male president of a family-owned art gallery is one of the owners is NOT sexist. Entire pages are lectures on woman's competition against man. I quit only a few pages in. Am making sure I never stumble and accidentally get something written by this author ever again.
title: Boring, woke content ruins the story

author: Love2Read
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2020
review_content: This was a pretty good book, in my opinion.  There were a few parts that were a little disjointed and some things put in that didn't really have anything to do with the story.  What I found confusing, there were parts where a character is having a conversation with someone but then you realize it was a conversation from the past they were remembering.  I get that, remembering something when you are talking to someone else, but it doesn't portray easy on a page.The characters were all kind of annoying.  Shallow and not very easy to like; I didn't like any of them.Even though I didn't like any of the characters and the writing was a bit difficult to follow at times, I gave 3 stars because it was a pretty good story.  Kind of easy to figure out the killer but still a good story.
title: Pretty good book.

author: Jen Jensen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2020
review_content: I’m not sure how to rate this. I love Luanne Rice and she’s one of the authors that I will pick up her books no matter what. So of course I got Last Day when I could. It was beautifully written and compelling, with situations and characters and thoughts that pulled me along. However, the tone is very very different than what I’m used to from Ms. Rice. This was not an intriguing, ultimately feel good drama with a romance woven through. This was intense and, much of the time, depressing. To the point where I almost didn’t pick it up again.I was going to rate it three stars because I really didn’t care for it. But for those of you who are looking for this sort of book, and because it was so well done, I’m giving it the five that the quality deserves.
title: Mixed feelings

author: Amanda Rose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: Ms. Rice consistently releases solid stories and Last Day is no exception. Secrets can bring people closer together but they can also tear them apart. There is no shortage of secrets in this story, some with devastating consequences. Who killed Beth is a mystery, and the journey to find her killer will keep you guessing. I enjoyed the growth of Beth’s sister Kate as the story progressed. A horrible and traumatic event changed the lives of the sisters and you get to see how they responded and how years later trauma continues to impact daily life. The violence is shocking but not so repeatedly described that it becomes gory. The heart of the story is the relationships between the characters, not the violence itself but the effects of the murder. A great read that pulls you in and holds your attention.
title: It’s not what you think...or is it?

author: Pammy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020
review_content: The book is well written but I just could not buy into the story line.  Beth is 6 months pregnant, with a 16 year old daughter and is murdered in her bedroom.  A famous painting is stolen from the house.  Over 20 years ago, her mother was murdered in their art gallery and the same famous painting stolen but later recovered.  The story meanders all over the place.  Her sister, Kate, is heartbroken but was already damaged from her mother’s murder.  The culprit could be the cheating husband, the homeless boyfriend (no wealthy Connecticut housewife has a boyfriend who lives in a tent), a former rapist/murderer who lives nearby or someone else entirely.  The sister seems to do more work than the detective who is busy falling in love with her.  There are 2 best friends, one who is gay, but the friends don’t seem to know her very well.  The missing artwork does not really figure into the story.  There is a wild rabbit who becomes instantly tame.  The revelation of who did it is wholly unsatisfactory and the motive unclear.
title: Too many unbelievable elements

author: Mia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2021
review_content: Leaves you hanging,  the ending made no sense. A supposed dedicated mother to savagely kill her Pregnant best friend and then cut you off without an explanation. What little was explained didn’t fit . The murderer had no motive other than the fact she was an alcoholic. Sorry I wasted my time and money
title: Time I can’t get back.  Disappointed

author: Rachelle H
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2020
review_content: I enjoyed this mystery because the writing was excellent. The setting was so real, almost a character in itself along the Connecticut shoreline.The book was very long and detailed, giving the backstory of most major characters, yet leaving out details that kept the reader questioning. Although, I enjoyed the careful creation of the mystery, I was a little disappointed at the end. Without spoiling it, I'll say that the motive and murderer left me unsatisfied because of the way the story was set up. But I did enjoy all the careful nuances of art, poetry, and setting that the author included in the story.*Content disclaimer: There were quite a few F bombs and some graphic details of violence and mentions of sex.
title: Hauntingly beautiful with some unanswered questions

author: Alvin4567
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
review_content: SPOILER ALERT!! Am I the only one who thought the ending was unbelievable? What in Scottie’s past indicated she was capable of something like this. If she was mad that Beth would not tell the fathers whose baby it was, why couldn’t she just tell them herself. Killing Beth and the baby was unnecessary and made no sense.The other issue I had with the book was it was too long. This was a whodunnit. Some character development is good and necessary, but the author went way overboard.
title: Contrived ending

author: Aimee Rogers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
review_content: I am always looking for new authors whose work I will love.  I thought since this book was recommended by an editor and was an early release because the editor chose it for the First Reads program that it had great potential.  The summary sounded interesting, so I decided to try it.  I saw LuAnn Rice had written many books, and I thought experience was a plus in an author.  I don't mean to be cruel, but I won't ever read another of her books.  I found the writing wooden and without feeling.  I didn't like any of the characters in the book.  I found them to be shallow and boring.  The plot was rather incohesive in my opinion.  I just did not care for this book specifically or the work in general.
title: Not For Me

author: Robert Krueger
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2020
review_content: Beth shines through in the opening pages -- pregnant and a lovely day streaming into her bedroom.  But this is deceptive; what is real?  Murder, mother and unborn child.  Something is not as it should be.  Something is hidden in her mind.  This is a mystery story, but equally it is  a study of the characters.The novel's descriptive passages  are clearly definitive bringing to light the atmosphere of the novel.  Personalities are thoroughly examined, integrating them into the story, with personality and the story running in parallel.  The author engulfs the emotional landscape as the story is told.  Reviewed by the author of The Children's Story, About Good and Evil.
title: Emotionally gripping

author: IrishMom52
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: Have read other Luanne Rice books and found this one falls short.  It is an extremely sad story of infidelity, secrets, betrayal, death, and emotional issues.  Should not be read by anyone dealing with any emotional problems.  Liked that the characters were well developed and each given their own history chapter.  Did not like the ending. It felt like, "if you haven't figured it out by now, here is the murderer".  Not her best work.
title: Not Rice's best

author: Nancy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2020
review_content: Rice has written a very suspenseful, page-turner of a novel.  The art theft and horrible murder of Kate and Beth's mother at their family's high-end art gallery when they are quite young starts this edgy novel and is followed years later by the theft of the same painting and the murder of one of the two daughters.  The roller coaster ride through friends and suspects that follows a curving, winding, and suspicious trail will have you guessing through the remainder of the book and, just when you're certain you know who's to blame for the murder, you'll find you're totally wrong.  Well written, with great characterizations, excellent scenery, and historical facts concerning history and art, Rice is a talented author that delivers a well-thought-out storyline.Would definitely recommend for all mystery fans!
title: Suspenseful Novel!

author: joe vitucci
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020
review_content: I thought the book very interesting for awhile, trying to figure out who committed the  murder, and how all of the people were intertwined. But it kept going on and on and......, and it started to bore me. Then we have the ending with a rabbit involved.  Really.Give me a break.  But I suppose there are many that enjoy this kind of book. And the author is prolific, so what do I know.Exactly.If you've read Luanne Rice before, you'll probably enjoy this.
title: A husband, or lover, or someone else?

author: Yuki A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
review_content: The writing was good, the pacing better than the last Kindle book I read (When She Returned 1-star read) BUT I took one star off for the incredibly weird 2 chapters inserted at the end where the dead character speaks in first person AFTER DYING and an additional two stars for the weak ending with a very thin "resolution". Mediocre read and a bit of a waste of my time.
title: Eh (and I'll explain why)

author: SML Grandma
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: Initially, I really enjoyed Last Day, but the end left way too many threads hanging. These were supposedly freinds for life from childhood and claimed continuing friendship into adulthood,  but the reality was that there was one who had betrayed them all in the most horrific way. The worst of it though, was that there was no real explanation for the betrayal. The reader was left hanging, trying to go back and piece together an explanation but I never found anything which helped to explain the why of it all. I had really enjoyed the book up until just before the end. The ending just left me scratching my head, wanting to understand the WHY of it all.
title: Too many questions remained.....

author: Callie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2020
review_content: What a wonderfully written book.  Since I haven’t read any novels by Luanne Rice, I wasn’t too sure if I would like it.  However, from the very first, I was drawn in by the characters and the mystery involving Beth’s murder surrounding the art world.  I love a book that actually inspires teaching you something new.  While the storyline kept you guessing, the inspiration about paintings kept me googling the artists and famous paintings.  Thank you for letting us readers delve into a world that we practically have no knowledge of, while writing a fabulous murder mystery around a beautifully written novel.  A for sure a five star bravo! ❤️
title: Beautifully written!

author: Jeanne  Campbell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: This is a book about a journey, a mystery, a tragedy and the power of love.  It teaches us to not make snap judgements.  To be aware of the people around us and realize who they have become over time. It’s a book about decisions and choices and sisters at heartFirstly I grew up in Connecticut and my family had a beach house on the shoreline. Mystic, new London, Groton, and the Saybrook lighthouses are all places I know so well. The author describes the Connecticut shoreline in amazing detail.  The story itself pulls you in and makes you care about the characters.  The story is perfectly woven to make the a book you can’t put down.If you love Danielle Steel or Barbara Bradford mixed with Patricia Cromwell you will love this book.
title: Perfect mystery and winter escape

author: Denise H. Walsh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2021
review_content: I thoroughly enjoyed this book so I shall give it  nine out of ten. it was been a few years since I'd read one of her books and now I'm back looking to follow this story farther if there is a farther.I fully recommend the book and it still left you with the believe there is something more. i thoroughly enjoyed the book and plan on reading more of her iterary style. I recommend it for sure as a book you can read on a plane,on a train, in the rain, in the sky , and for a break try reading it at the laundry, in the line at the post office, at  the grocery store but better pay for it first and my favorite is to read it in bed..
title: a melding of sisters and friends looking for a killer

author: Chels
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2020
review_content: This book was very hard to set down. It got to a point where during my idle time I was thinking and analyzing the characters in the story to try and piece it all together. I loved the twists and turns it took and that it kept me guessing and second guessing throughout the entire story. Every character goes through their own battles I appreciated the personal perspectives of some of the minor characters. Overall I really enjoyed this story and the descriptiveness of it.If you're into murder mysteries, I'd recommend this.My first story by Luanne Rice. You've just gained another fan.
title: Kept me on the edge

author: Sabrina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
review_content: I've read a lot of Ms. Rice's books over the years & I'm never disappointed.  This was a very good story, based on an interesting premise - do traumas in our past affect not just us, but those around us & how? Being a trauma survivor & knowing that those effects have affected my own behaviors which in turn have affected others...yes, this novel really spike to me.I loved the details about the art, the landscape & how those two things were woven into such a colorful tapestry that, once the last thread showed, tied it all together into a complete picture. Definitely glad I purchased this book, i highly recommend it!
title: Twists, Turns & a Surprise ending!

author: Nancy Ostrowski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2020
review_content: This story really had me from the beginning. I enjoyed the characters, the plot with its twists and turns, and trying to see where the surprise was going to come. What ruined it for me was not the plot, but that towards the end of the book, the author employed an unexpected technique: having a chapter from the deceased person’s point of view. The chapter added nothing to the story and derailed the momentum of rapport I was building was the characters. I spent more time feeling derailed by this late-in-the-game switch than I did processing what she was saying. The final chapter was also from the deceased’s POV, which made for an unsatisfactory finale. If the author wanted to write a supernatural mystery, this technique should have been employed in Chapter 1, where it would have set the tone instead of being jarring. I may try another book by this author, but more cautiously.
title: Almost satisfying

author: CasasCristina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2020
review_content: A school of fish. A price of lions. A conflict of emotions. If a man is a cuckold, what is the cheated-on woman called? This is the story of women friends and a murder. What rings true is how friends can choose with whom they share which secret while loving equally. What rings false is the worship of the dead woman- there is never a good reason for the idolatry in which her memory is held. As for the male characters? Stereotypical. So why did I enjoy the book? The writing wasn't bad, the story propelled and yes, I wanted to know the secrets. Rated between a 2 - 3  ( how do you create a half-star?)
title: A conflict of emotions

author: laura cruz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: This book kept me on edge from the very beginning. It was like I knew each character, their personalities, what made them tick, all because of the author brings them to life for the reader.. Every chapter took you to a new adventure, a new twist in the story, it made all your senses come alive. This book makes you think about life‘s choices and friendships along the way. I would totally recommend this Book. It would be great for book clubs who actually read the book! I learned a lot about art, sailing and deep wounds but heal and some of the won’t . Do yourself a favor and read this book!
title: Must read - needs to be a movie!

author: Marine Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
review_content: I got this book as a "read for free" from Amazon Prime. Having read it, I would happily pay full price.This story, more mystery than thriller, delves into the many ways we love and the many ways different people in our lives inspire love. Then it twists to describe how loving so much can mangle a person to commit the most vile acts.Rice does an amazing job of bringing, not only her characters, but their colliding worlds to brilliant and totally absorbing life. This is the kind of read that makes you yearn to know the answers, while dreading the end of the book. It's just that good.
title: The Things We Do for Love

author: Betsy Georgitis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: This book about a young mom’s murder was engaging enough to to keep me reading.  I found the characters interesting although a bit stereotypical. I didn’t figure out the murderer until close to the end of the book.  The author was good at suggesting possible suspects and their possible motivation for murder. The actual murderer’s motivation for the killing was rather weak. It was difficult to believe he/she would commit a brutal murder.
title: Kept me interested

author: Maggie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
review_content: This is my first time reading a book by this author and I'm impressed.  The book captured me on the first page and kept my attention throughout.  I felt as though I could see where the characters were located on any given page without the boredom that often comes with such descriptions.  I felt as though I knew the characters, the comfortable introduction of each was so well done.  Even with all this I had trouble identifying the killer.  I had trouble putting this book down and was delighted it was waiting for me when I could pick it up again.I really enjoyed this story and will look into more books by Luanne Rice.  Yes, I will read this book again.
title: Wonderful Book

author: Dlee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: I don't understand the criticizm at all.  It's a story, no one ever said they have to be 100% factual.  For me it was an interesting enjoyable read.  Sure, the opening and reason for the story is a little hard to take but so is just about everything you see in the news today.  I had never read anything by this author and I will look into her other books now.  It was edited well, not much foul language and yes it perhaps a was little long at times but I haven't found a "perfect" author to please everyone yet.  This one fits into my very likeable folder.
title: Enjoyed the Story

author: stephen g. carroll
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: This was an interesting and compelling book from LuAnn Rice. Two sisters who were bound by a terrible tragedy, and love each other deeply deal with it in different ways. Kate, becomes a pilot who has great difficulty developing relationships, whereas Beth runs the family art gallery, is loved by all, and appears to be in a happy marriage. Everything falls apart on the day that pregnant Beth is found murdered. The very surprising ending is who the actual killer was and why. Some very good character developments is part of why I enjoyed this book.
title: Last Day

author: Rochelle  L. Holt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2020
review_content: As I'm a Luanne Rice fan and have read many of her novels, I was disappointed at her new genre, the common mystery.  This one was too long and not credible at all.  It wasn't even written in her usual style although it wasdescriptive.However, the characters were flat and the outcome was so disappointing and unbelievable.  I hope the authorreturns to her stories that are believable with characters the reader can relate to regarding relationship issues.Yes, there were conflicts here but violence never appeals tho it's rampant in our society.
title: DISAPPOINTING

author: David C. Howell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
review_content: When reading the “editorial reviews,” from “best selling authors,” I had to wonder if they don’t all enter an agreement of “you praise my book, l’ll praise yours.”  Certainly, many of the reviews from actual Amazon reviewers, by and large, don’t lavish on this book the same high praise of the  pros.  And the average reader is right.  No need to repeat everything said here, but, at the end, I said to myself, “Tell me again—who claims to have killed this person?  And why again did they say the did it?”  A pretty good book in places but the ending made the time spent reading it less worthwhile.
title: Pretty Average Overall

author: CAROL CUSTER
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2020
review_content: The author had me hooked on the first page.  She set the scene perfectly for the story that would follow.  The characters were all interesting and complex, the setting well-described, and the narrative slowly fed us the story with plenty of twists and turns along the way.Though I, like Conor, wanted one person to be guilty, it was just too easy and too predictable.  The final reveal was a shocking surprise - - and a very sad one in many ways.Overall, I really enjoyed the book - - an engrossing thriller.
title: ENGROSSING THRILLER

author: lovetoread
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: tired of reading books where political views are input I dont care about their views, tired of reading about women can do anything, many women were strong invicible single parents we can do anything we want  but don't write a whole book about this stuff, just get to the core of the story, don't really care their grandmother was a single parent went against society, as if that makes this book better why not write about the story, oh by the way don't need to read about descriptive things that happen to the body when murdered, if that what it takes to write a good book these days, spare me from sending anymore money
title: very political

author: Two G's
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2021
review_content: First (and last) book from this author for me.  No quality in the writing and on top of that the story was horrible.  For some reason I kept with it, probably hopeful things would get better for at least one of the characters!  I was shocked to see how many books this author has published but I suppose there is a book for every reader.
title: Boring and Depressing

author: jay jay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2020
review_content: and I read about three books a week.  The author plays words as a master musician plays her instrument, coaxing myriad feelings from the words, leading the reader quickly at times, then slowing with gentleness at others.The story crafted by Ms. Rice was exquisite.  Her characters were realistic, never shallow caricatures.  The mystery was maintained to the end, and the ending didn't favor, "... and they all lived happily ever after".  It concluded with survival and all its challenges and rewards to come.
title: One of the best books I've read in a long time,

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2020
review_content: This story will captivate from the beginning!  Two beautiful sisters, raised in privilege, torn apart by a tragedy in their early years.  A police officer works the case and takes a special interest in the sisters so traumatized.  He takes a special interest in making sure they remain safe over the years.  Then tragedy strikes again when one of the sisters is brutally murdered!  How can he solve the case when he's so sure he knows who committed the murder?  Lots of twists and turns!  It will hold your interest till the end.  Yes, an excellent read!
title: Excellent read!

author: RamD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: I downloaded this book as one of the January reads. I could not put the book down. The suspense, in the book is delightful. After the murder of Beth, the author keeps you guessing as to the name of murderer. Just when you think you have figured out as to who murdered Beth, there are new twists and turns and you are brought back to “ground zero” to, once again, guess the name of the murderer. You have to wait until the last chapter, when everything is revealed. Luann Rice does not disappoint and throughout the book you witness the mastery of the author, who keeps you in constant-suspense. It is not surprising that Ms Rice has written many best-sellers. This book is worth buying.
title: Delightful  mystery that keeps you guessing

author: Kris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: I chose this rating because the characters remained in my thoughts during the hours I couldn't keep reading. The character that surprised me although there were hints was Scotty.  The novel presented how tragedy leaves lasting effects, especially when encountered during formative years.  How each individual responds is the crux of the novel.  I found myself needing to talk about  how  the complexity of emotion, jealousy, judge mentalism can evoke violence and betrayal.  Last Day was  a much deeper work than I had anticipated.
title: Kept me wondering

author: J. R. Kamen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2020
review_content: This book is excellent, very well written. I am not a great reviewer but I try. The author has an ability to paint a picture with words. Having never been to the location where the story takes place, I had no trouble seeing everything she describes.  A really great murder mystery with all kinds of twists. Her knowledge of the location and art and history is awesome.I only gave this book 4 stars because it gets just a little too girlie for me. For me some of that could be left out without taking anything away from the story.
title: Excellent book

author: Weenerdog
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
review_content: I became hooked on Rice's writing when I read "Follow The Stars Home" and was really looking forward to reading her latest release.This particular story was hard for me to get in to from the start.  Usually, I'll read a Rice book within a few days.  But it took several days for me to finally force myself to finish it up.The story was very depressing with little relief.  The killer's motive was just beyond weird.  The characters aren't very interesting.  The detective on the case had a non-healthy fixation on the sisters because of a previous case that involved them years prior.I could go on about other things that I didn't care for, but why bother?  I can't really recommend this one.
title: Not Rice's best by a long shot

author: jgU014
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: Sometimes we bottle up grief and hide it away...the main character has been frozen by it for decades... But those who choose to wander through the story of these characters have ample opportunity to exercise their own grief while engaging in the questioning, doubt, and grief of the many individuals involved in this tale.It is serendipitous that Kate  begins resolving her own grief through a symbolic act toward the end, just as the reader utilizes the story to symbolize his/her own grief and move toward catharsis...
title: A great read for grieving

author: Leslie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: The story is about four friends, two of them sisters. Twenty three years ago, the sisters and their mother, were held captive during an art robbery.  It went tragically wrong.  The storyline begins, as one of the sisters is later murdered. The family and friends are left to wonder, what happened, who is to blame?  I also pondered on this, as I read.  The story was well written, but somewhat sad at times.  Goes to show that having it all, doesn't mean you will always be happy, or have no problems.
title: Her last day was a sad day

author: Bookworm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2020
review_content: I'd forgotten how much I liked Luanne Rice's books until I bought this one! Now, I'm going to have to go back and read all the ones I missed!  She has a way of getting your attention and keeping it right to the end of the book and always, surprised and wanting to know more! This book kept me guessing right down to the finish line and even then, once I'd figured out who the killer was, I still had a hard time believing the reason why it ended like it did and how they all lived with the answers.
title: A shattering betrayal, an unbelievable revelation!

author: Gerald D. Matzke
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2020
review_content: This was an interesting story with somewhat of a surprise ending.  My reason for the three-star  rating is that there was too much time spent with characters'  thoughts.  I can appreciate some of it to help develop the character but it seemed to me that this was just padding to make the book longer.  One thing that comes through loud and clear is that people are often more than they present, even to those who think they know them well.  In this story, even the victim was more than she seemed.
title: A Long Journey

author: jan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
review_content: This book caught my attention from the first page.  The descriptions of every aspect of the book was excellent.  Unfortunately, parts of the story were far fetched.  One minor thing that bugged me, the author interchanged the name of the detective constantly:  sometimes referring to him as Connor and sometimes Reid.  (Reid Connor).  Possible Spoiler alert:  I didn't buy the end (motivation of the killer) at all.  Very dissapointed.  I would have rated this a 5 had it not been for the ending.
title: Page Turner but fell short of a great read.

author: Kelly Buzan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2021
review_content: I have read almost all of Luanne Rice's books and enjoyed them very much but this one was quite a disappointment.  Starting with a horrific murder it then wandered through a large cast of mostly stereotypical characters before falling completely flat. I got through about 3/4 of it before I just skipped to the end.
title: Disappointed

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
review_content: I haven't read anything this potent in a long time! The story is about a murder of a young pregnant woman and both the investigation into her murder and her past.  She's surrounded by long time friends and her sister and the memory of her mother's death during a robbery.The characters are all flawed in various ways which makes them feel like they're your neighbors!  The writing is excellent and she created clear visuals for the reader to experience.  Until the very end I had absolutely NO idea who murdered Beth. Those who were suspects each had a had great alibi.I recommend this book without reservations!
title: WOW !

author: swagcass
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2020
review_content: Beautifully written story that reflects the hearts of those who love, hurt, destroy and are devastated in a picturesque town. Who killed this mother--and why? Like the impressionist art noted in the book, there are many small colorful pieces but until you step back and see how all the parts form a whole, you can't find the answer.
title: A mystery of hearts

author: Eric Van Lustbader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
review_content: I got this as part of the First Reads program, and was pretty excited to read it. What a disappointment. A crashing bore, written in the blandest style imaginable, with a too-well-worn plot, and paper-thin characters. Not worth my time.
title: So generic it's painful

author: Joey'sback
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
review_content: As an avid reader of mysteries and action thrillers,  I was intrigued by the "blurbs" about this novel.  What I found was so much more than what I had expected!!  It turned in dozens of directions,  and taught me lessons in beauty,  poetry and nature along with being an intriguing murder mystery.  (I did figure out who the "perp" was,  but it wasn't æ slam dunk!  Lol)There is a love story,  of sorts,  and lots of psychology,  gorgeous scenery,  and characters you love (and then hate,  and then love again...)Highly recommend!!
title: Excellent,  Beautiful,  Impossible to Forget

author: Teri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: I received an ARC from NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. This tragic mystery is an absolutely fantastic book!! Written with panache, the characters make this story real. Luanne Rice's research for this novel throws it into a category of its own. The twists, the turns, the realism will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end. Plan on reading in one sitting because you will not be able to put this book down once you've opened the cover. Enjoy! 📚
title: Fantastic book!

author: GCMcMahan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
review_content: I am avid reader of what is now a new term called "Cozy" Mysteries!  A fast read.  This was my first Luanne Rice book. The  story line was interesting and kept you guessing but I was bored with the many pages of long descriptions of people, places and things which could have been condensed and was totally  irrelevant to the plot.  It seemed the author just tried to fill the pages of "stuff" to lengthen the book.  This would not be a book I would recommend.
title: Great Plot

author: Jo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2020
review_content: This story drew me in from the first page when Beth is found murdered in her bed in what appears to be a crime related to a painting - the same painting that was part of a crime 23 years ago that took the life of Beth’s mom. There are twists and turns, suspense, family and friends, love and betrayal all combined to keep the reader guessing as to who killed Beth. I thought I had it figured out a couple of times and was proven wrong. I did figure out who the murderer was, but I didn’t know motive until it was revealed near the end of the book.
title: Great book!

author: Dennis Freeman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2020
review_content: It's been a week since I finished this novel and still trying to put my finger on why I found it unsatisfying. Certainly it's well written, and she keeps you guessing about the murderers identity. But the characters don't really come alive. I wanted to care more about the daughter and the dead woman. Artistically I think changing the viewpoint to move the story along is a bit of copout, she even gives the dead woman a chapter to fill in a few final details.
title: A little cold, you don't really get to know or love the characters

author: R. McQ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2020
review_content: The first few chapters did not grab my attention, but the story became engrossing for me after that. The plot held my interest. I couldn’t wait to find out who the killer was. However, the ending completely fell apart. It lacked any reasonable motive for the killing, and there was nothing in the personality to make me believe the character was even capable of murder. And why was the murder committed in the manner it was done? Not to mention the last chapter was way out of left field.
title: MANY UNANSWERED QUESTIONS!

author: Dale E. Ramsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
review_content: I suspected right up until the end that her husband killed her. What a surprise that it turned out to be her friend.Loved the ending when she let her sister and the rabbit go.It was horrible what their father did that caused their mother’s death. So much sorrow.
title: Great Read

author: Linda Clark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2020
review_content: This is the worst book I have read in a long time.  I kept reading only to find out "who did it". To do so I started to skip whole pages.  If I were a publisher this would have never been published.  The author went over and over the time of being tied up in the basement with the dead mother for Pete's sake 8 times.the suspense that was dropped in from time to time was contrived and amatuerish.  And the last half of the book I thought the author rambled about other topics.  I just won't read any more of her books.
title: Last Day

author: CP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2020
review_content: Disappointing read. I wanted very much to enjoy this book, but I found it completely unrealistic with a very forced plot. I couldn’t get lost in the story as it was not believable right from the first flash-back depicting the tragic event in which the sisters lost their mother. Unfortunately I have an annoying habit of not being able to put down a book without finishing it (could there be something ahead that will make it all worthwhile?), because this is where I should have stopped reading.
title: Not worth the time.

author: Carolann C. McGrath
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
review_content: This is a very well written story of Beth's last day and who killed her.  There are a number of suspects including her husband,  Pete.  Kate, her sister was convinced it was Pete, so was the detective who had handled the case when her mother was murdered years before.  A painting, Moonlight,  was stolen both times.  Is this why Beth was murdered.  You'll read about 85%  of the book before you find out who the murderer is.  I enjoyed this book.
title: A good who done it

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: I read mysteries a lot that my favorite genre of books. This one had me reading until all hours of the morning as I could not figure out who the murderer was in this story. It was not until the last chapter that one found out "whodunnit" it. I like to thank it's because this author's writing is just that good and not because I just can't figure out what might be right in front of my nose! I would recommend this book to any reader who's interested and a "can't put the book down it's so good"!
title: Best mystery I have read in a long time.

author: J Taylor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: If you have nothing better to do, and want a "quick read" unburdened by thought, this is a book for you. I get the concepts: even the closest friends keep secrets from each other, and childhood trauma creates lifelong impact. But this story itself, the plotline, the characters were so ridiculous. I feel like it was written based on a formula for readers who don't want to think as they read.
title: Not for lovers of literature

author: j.r.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: I can't remember if I've read this author before. I agree with other reviewers in that the book did feel long to me and there were parts that probably could have been edited out without much affecting the story. I also agree that once "dead beth" became a narrator, the book became a bit weird for me.The perpetrator was not who I thought. I'm not so good at figuring out "whodunit" so other readers may have a different experience.
title: A bit overwritten.

author: Noveldig
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
review_content: I don't normally post bad reviews, but this book was so boring. The characters (all of them) said the same thing over and over and over. I found myself skipping pages to get to the end of the chapter. 55 % through the book,  I  skipped to the last chapter to see if I was right about the murder's identity. I was.
title: So glad I didn't pay for this book

author: Tara Lyn Corey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
review_content: Sorry to all the people that did not enjoy this book but I loved it. 1st book I read like this, I usually read rom com.  The book had a lots of twists and turns first you thought it was someone then you thought it was someone else I enjoyed it I would recommend it.
title: I enjoyed my free 1st read of the year

author: Wildfire
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2020
review_content: Loved by everyone, family and friends , the lovely Beth isBrutally murdered.Police focus immediately on Pete, less lovable husband who currently has both a mistress and Her new baby. But all have too many secrets that must be explored. Believable characters make interesting reading as story unfolds complicated their all too human flaws and failings.Kept me interested till the last page. Writing style was a definite plus
title: Love and Murder

author: Heidi M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
review_content: I wanted to like this but was frustrated on many levels. Maybe because I find the premise of "best friends forever" who "never reveal" each other's secrets  a little artificial I could never truly connect with the characters.  I felt there were inconsistencies in details of the story as well as the characterizations. Some of the behaviors didn't ring true for me.  I also felt the details of the murder were unecessarily repeated and they felt "off" given the perpetrator.
title: disappointing

author: Cyn Bean
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2020
review_content: Hard to put down, I kept thinking a mother and a baby murdered. Hard to take: someone I barely knew, his daughter was murdered. She was a pregnant woman, was sliced open and her infant taken. They were caught and now the grandfather raises his grandson. I kept thinking why couldn’t the baby have lived, something left for them all to love. So this book for me was a page turner hard to put down and not until the end did I have a clue. Very good because I usually figure it out early on when I’m reading. I’ll have to read some more of your books. First one for me. Well done!
title: Unbelievable as I read on!

author: Lisa K.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2020
review_content: Started cold with a brutal murder. I wasn't expecting that, I don't enjoy the way mysteries tease and toy with the reader, I did not enjoy spending time with the character who probably did it or the family's icky backstory. Picked up on Prime Reads. The writing was fine and included some discussion about art that I couldn't enjoy because of the terrible murder at the top. I only made it 60 pages in. I'm not this author's audience.
title: Starts with a brutal murder of a woman, couldn't get past that

author: Jari Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2020
review_content: The book is among the very worst I've ever bothered reading.  Had to give it a 1 star since there is nothing lower.  I did finish it simply because I wanted to see what in the world she would dream up to end it with.  The characters are superficial.  The plot is interesting but not developed well.
title: Don't waste your time

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
review_content: It starts with a horrific murder. The adult victim was a victim once before. The baby she carried never took a breath. I kept reading, sometimes losing sleep, to find out who did it and why. I thought that I would feel some closure.  When I got to the end, I realized that knowing the killer did not bring me any peace. The crime was too senseless.  I did not rate the book only three stars because it was badly written. On the contrary, it was well written. I just didn't like the circumstances of the story
title: Gripping

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2020
review_content: I have always been a pretty voracious reader but I now have severe joint problems resulting in reduced mobility reading is what saves my life. I read all genres with no particular favorite but they do need to be well written. Stilted dialogue ridiculous plotting or lazy writing turn me off real quick. I had never read Ms. Rice before but I certainly will now. The plot of Last Day is suspenseful and believable the character are rich and deep the writing is absolutely beautiful. Ms. Rice is a master her words flow so smoothly she obviously does extensive research on her subject matter and you will almost certainly learn something from her. I won't rehash the story i could never do it justice but I will strongly recommend this book.  If you're wavering just read it you will be glad you did
title: Beautifully told story

author: Kindle reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2020
review_content: I enjoyed the book until the end when the "ghost" got a chapter to explain her motives and feelings...blah!I suspected who the killer was several chapters before it was revealed, but was totally disappointed that no real explanation was given. author: Terry Skones

review_content: I have always been a Luanne Rice fan. This book did not disappoint me. I like how her books combine sisters or friends and this had both. title: Luanne Rice thriller!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2021
review_content: This takes place in Connecticut & surrounding area.  It's about a family that had a local art gallery. title: Continuously interesting!

author: Bonnie B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: This book was a trip into a different world of the privileged monied artists and bespoke families of galleries and ivy league colleges. The uncovering of this aberration is the point of the story, and the way it is brought to light is a good read.
title: You never really know anyone...

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2020
review_content: I really liked the book. The storyline was interesting, the characters entertaining, and the artistic and literary references were informative. I don't think I'd buy another from this author. I feel like l wasted hours reading because the ending was unsatisfying.
title: Almost perfect

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020
review_content: This novel is about four teenage friends who remain friends into their thirties when this tale begins with the brutal murder of one of the four - a very pregnant Beth. title: Love and secrets

author: Kristin1724

review_content: I kept reading, but the writing was really so poorly done. There was no nuance, no character depth, stilted dialogue, and the story just never came together in an engaging way. title: It wasn’t great...

author: DKane

author: Kindle Customer

title: Not my cup of tea

author: JE
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2020
review_content: I first was very intrigued by this book.  However, the meandering story line left me frustrated and the ending was really weird. title: Strange Ending

author: Annie Athens

title: A Waste of Time

author: Susan James

title: True Story With A Twist

author: Sandy B

I found the ending to be hopeful with tinges of sadness and a little bit of magic.  Great read!

author: Deborah A. G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020

author: Dee

review_content: I gave this novel a four star rating because of the author's style.  I love how she let the murder victim speak to the audience yet did not give the identity of the perpetrator. If you lean towards murder  mystery then you will enjoy this book.

author: PMP- Mpls.

author: Cathy  'Cat' Drum

title: Another great read with a little romance and a lot of suspence! Would be a wonderful way to spend a rainy/stormy day!

author: Cooky

author: Big Time Book Junkie

author: Diane Balding

title: Amazing

author: Jann
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
